awd_titl_txt: New Reactions and Strategies in Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Division of Chemistry supports the research group of Professor Myers of Harvard University to develop new methods for the facile construction of complex molecules in the laboratory.  This research focuses on three areas: 1) the investigation of scope and utility of a new auxiliary for asymmetric synthesis; 2) the development of new methods for the synthesis of substituted tetrahydroisoquinolines and isoquinolines; and 3) the development of storable reagents for alkene labeling in aqueous media.  New transformations that form carbon-carbon and carbon-nitrogen bonds with absolute stereo-chemical control will be investigated.  The products proposed for synthesis have great promise for potential applications in the pharmaceutical industry and may provide new ligand platforms for metal-catalyzed transformations.  The discovery of new transformations in synthetic chemistry has inherent intellectual merit, as well as practical application. Frequently, new methods in synthetic organic chemistry lead to new understanding of basic reaction mechanisms or to the development of completely new views of chemical reactivity, and initiate cycles of further discovery and insight. 

The research is by design of practical nature, thus, it is conceivable that innovations from the work might find industrial application, such as in fine-chemical or pharmaceutical product synthesis. Developments in synthetic organic chemistry have tremendous benefit to society.  Basic research in the field of chemical synthesis is necessary to provide scientists from all areas the tools that they need to rapidly and reliably construct new molecular structures, for any conceivable purpose.  Potential applications include the discovery of new pharmaceutical agents, agricultural products, and materials, as well as the development of more efficient and/or environmentally beneficial industrial processes.  This research will also provide training for graduate students, preparing them for careers in academia and chemical industries.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
Significant Results: 1) We have demonstrated that aldolization of pseudoephenamine glycinamide with aldehydes and ketones affords practical access to diverse syn -β -hydroxy-α -amino acids in optically pure form. This is significant because these products form the basis for the synthesis of at least five different classes of important antibiotics, as our research has shown. Thus, we anticipate that our research, which is no longer funded by the NSF, might directly lead to the discovery of new antibiotics.  Application of this method with chiral ketones as substrates allows for the production of β , β ’-disubstituted-β -hydroxy-α -amino acids, a genre of non-proteinogenic amino acids not easily prepared by other means. 2) We have also demonstrated that the Michael addition of pseudoephenamine glycinamide with α ,β -unsaturated enones affords practical access to cyclic imines and 1,5-dicarbonyl derivatives in optically pure form, which could be further transformed to substituted non-proteinogenic prolines and glutamic acids.

Intellectual Merit: The discovery of new transformations in synthetic chemistry has inherent intellectual merit, as well as practical application. Frequently, new methods in synthetic organic chemistry lead to new understanding of basic reaction mechanisms or to the development of completely new views of chemical reactivity, and initiate cycles of further discovery and insight.

Broader Impacts: Developments in synthetic organic chemistry have tremendous benefit to society. Potential applications include the discovery of new pharmaceutical agents, agricultural products, and materials, as well as the development of more efficient and/or environmentally beneficial industrial processes. Basic research in the field of chemical synthesis is necessary to provide scientists from all areas the tools that they need to rapidly and reliably construct new molecular structures, for any conceivable purpose. Although the tools of synthetic chemistry are powerful, it is nevertheless the case that chemical synthesis is often the rate-determining step in any scientific or industrial enterprise that involves new chemical entities and that the predictive quality of synthesis in many cases is low. The development of new biocompatible labeling reactions (in water) promises manifold impacts, including potential applications in target identification studies, imaging experiments, as well as other areas.


Last Modified: 05/31/2016
Modified by: Andrew G Myers
